context: Furthermore, the Tps1 gene isolated from maize was expressed in E. coli and was shown to encode a synthase catalyzing the formation of three sesquiterpene products (E)-β-farnesene, (E)-nerolidol, and (E,E)-farnesol. Therefore, MtEBOS appears to function as many other plant terpene synthases, in producing (E)-β-ocimene as the major product and smaller amounts of other terpenes. The Arabidopsis AtTPS03 gene appears to have a shared function with MtEBOS, as it also encodes a protein that synthesizes a major product (E)-β-ocimene (94%) and two minor products, (Z)-β-ocimene (4%) and myrcene (2%), and in addition AtTPS03 is induced in response to wounding and JA treatment. An (E)-β-ocimene synthase from L. japonicus, also synthesizes similar ratios of the same products, and is induced in response to spider mite infestation and mechanical wounding.Sequence analysis of (E)-β-ocimene synthase The MtEBOS sequence shows a high level of similarity with known (E)-β-ocimene synthases (Fig. 2 ). Not surprisingly, the highest level of conservation is with the enzyme characterized in another legume, L. japonicus, which is 67% identical and 81% similar at the amino acid sequence level. The sequences of (E)-β-ocimene synthases of both legume species contain a variation of the conserved RRx8W motif, in which the position of the second arginine contains a lysine (RKx8W). The RRx8W motif is characteristic of most monoterpene synthases members of the subfamily Tps-b  .

llm_generation.summary: (3e)-3,7-dimethylocta-1,3,6-triene is indirectly related to mite infestations through its role as a product of terpene synthases, which are induced in response to such infestations. The context discusses the synthesis of (E)-β-ocimene, a compound that may play a role in plant defense mechanisms against pests like spider mites. However, the specific relationship between (3e)-3,7-dimethylocta-1,3,6-triene and mite infestations is not explicitly detailed, making the connection more general.
